sequence.notes: Thiolate attacks a mesylate leaving group, forming a new carbon-sulfur bond.
Hydrolysis of a gem-dimethoxy ketal to a ketone, and conversion of a 1,2-dimethoxy ether to an aldehyde.
Intramolecular cyclization forming a bicyclic thiane derivative with new chiral centers, catalyzed by D-proline.
Methylation of a secondary alcohol to a methyl ether.
(5 steps)
Ketone is selectively reduced to a secondary alcohol with sodium borohydride.
The hydroxyl group on the bicyclic system is protected as a methoxymethyl (MOM) ether.

Syn-dihydroxylation of the alkene to form a 1,2-diol. The hydroxyl groups are added to opposite faces of the former double bond relative to each other (anti), but their relative stereochemistry is cis across the ring system (syn-addition to the alkene). The hydroxyl group closer to the MOMO group is directed 'down' (dashed bond), and the hydroxyl group closer to the benzyloxyethyl chain is directed 'up' (wedged bond). The H atom on the latter carbon is also 'up'.
Protection of vicinal diol as an isopropylidene acetal.
Deprotection of a MOMO ether to a hydroxyl group using trifluoroacetic acid.
Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone.
Nucleophilic addition of an enolate (derived from the ketone) to an aldehyde, forming a beta-hydroxy ketone.

substeps.notes: Thiolate attacks a mesylate, displacing it to form a thioether.
Acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of the dimethoxy acetal to an aldehyde and the cyclic dimethoxy ketal to a ketone.
Intramolecular cyclization involving aldehyde, ketone, and sulfide to form a complex bicyclic system. Likely an aldol/Michael type reaction.

Conversion of a secondary alcohol to a methyl ether. MsCl and pyridine are typically used to form a mesylate, which is then displaced by a methylating agent (e.g., methanol, though not explicitly shown in the conditions).
Elimination of methoxy group and adjacent hydrogen to form an alkene.
Stereoselective reduction of a cyclic ketone to a secondary alcohol using sodium borohydride.
Alcohol is protected as a methoxymethyl (MOM) ether.
Syn-dihydroxylation of an alkene using osmium tetroxide.
Protection of a vicinal 1,2-diol as an isopropylidene acetal using 2,2-dimethoxypropane under acidic conditions.
Desulfurization of a bicyclic dithiane to an acyclic alcohol, with concomitant hydrogenolysis of a benzyl ether to an alcohol.
Dehydration of primary alcohol to terminal alkene
Ozonolysis of terminal alkene to aldehyde, preserving acetal and MOMO protecting group.

sequence.notes: Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone. Yield across 2 steps.
Formation of an enol acetate from a β-diketone via kinetic deprotonation and trapping with acetyl chloride.
Reduction of a ketone to a secondary alcohol using sodium borohydride. The newly formed alcohol shows specific stereochemistry (OH down, H up).
Hydroxyl group converted to mesylate.
Methyl migration, double bond reduction, and ketone formation, with loss of acetate and mesylate groups from the original chain structure.
5 steps
Reduction of a ketone to a secondary alcohol using lithium aluminum hydride.
Acetylation of a secondary alcohol to an acetate ester.
Desulfurization of the 1,3-dithiane (thioketal) and benzyl thioether, and debenzylation of the benzyl ether using Raney Ni.
Grieco dehydration of a primary alcohol to a terminal alkene.
Ozonolysis of terminal alkene to aldehyde.
Aldehyde converted to β-hydroxy thioester via reaction with tert-butyl thioester enolate.
Deprotonation alpha to the thioester using t-BuLi/TMEDA, followed by reprotonation with acetic acid. No net structural change is observed in the product compared to the reactant.
Hydrolysis of the thioester to a methyl ester and hydrolysis of the acetate to a hydroxyl group. The MOMO group and the two isopropylidene ketals remain intact.
Selective acylation of a secondary alcohol with phenoxyacetic anhydride.
Mesylation of a secondary alcohol to form a mesylate ester.
Mesylate displacement by azide with stereochemical inversion at the reaction center.
Reduction of an azide group to an amine using hydrogen and platinum dioxide catalyst. All other functional groups and stereocenters remain unchanged.
Amine acylation with p-nitrophenyl chloroformate
Hydrolysis of two isopropylidene acetals and a MOMO ether to form multiple hydroxyl groups, while retaining the methyl ester and 4-nitrophenyl carbamate.
Deprotection of p-nitrophenyl carbamate and subsequent intramolecular cyclization to form a cyclic carbamate.
Formation of a cyclic mesitaldehyde acetal from adjacent diols (C10 and C11) in a 14-membered macrocyclic carbamate.
Methyl ester group is transformed into an ethyl thioester group via reaction with lithium ethylthiolate.
Exchange of the ethyl thioester with a pyridine-2-yl thioester.
Intramolecular Corey-Nicolaou lactonization of a seco-thioester to form a 14-membered macrolactone, concurrently forming a 5-membered cyclic carbamate. The Mesityl acetal remains.
N-acylation of the secondary amide with 4-phenylbenzoyl chloride (p-PhBzCl)
Hydrolysis of an N-acyl oxazolidinone (cyclic carbamate) to yield a secondary amide and a hydroxyl group.
Hydrolysis of a cyclic mesityl acetal to yield corresponding diol.
O-glycosylation of C5-hydroxyl of the macrolactone with a thioglycoside donor, resulting in anomeric inversion.

substeps.notes: Formation of a 4,6-O-benzylidene acetal from a methyl glucoside.

The product structure shown in the screenshot is identical to the reactant structure, which is chemically inconsistent with a periodate oxidation of a vicinal diol. The SMILES provided for the product reflects the drawn (identical) structure.

Formation of a phenylhydrazone from a methyl 4,6-O-(phenylmethylene)glucopyranoside derivative. The C3 alcohol is converted to a carbonyl, which then reacts with phenylhydrazine, eliminating water and losing the stereocenter at C3.
Catalytic hydrogenation of an azo group to an amine, retaining sugar stereochemistry and acetal protection.
N-acetylation of amine and O-acetylation of secondary alcohol
Hydrolysis of a 4,6-O-benzylidene acetal to form a 1,2-diol (specifically, opening of the acetal ring to reveal C4-OH and C6-CH2OH).
Two hydroxyl groups are converted to mesyloxy groups.
Iodide displacement of mesylates (occurs in 2 steps)
Reductive dehalogenation of a vicinal di-iodide to a methyl group and a methylene group using catalytic hydrogenation.
Hydrolysis of an acetamide and an acetate ester under basic conditions.
Reductive amination of a primary amine to a tertiary dimethylamine using formaldehyde and formic acid (Eschweiler-Clarke reaction).
Acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of a methyl acetal (O-methyl glycoside) to a hemiacetal, resulting in an anomeric mixture at the C2 position.

Mitsunobu reaction converting an anomeric alcohol (unspecified stereochemistry) to a 2-pyrimidinylthio group with inversion of stereochemistry. The N,N-dimethylamino group and a secondary alcohol remain untouched.
Alcohol is converted to a methyl carbonate using methyl chloroformate.

sequence.notes: Hydrolysis of the 2'-O-(methoxycarbonyl) group on the desosamine sugar. Part of Erythromycin A synthesis (Woodward 1981).
Acylation of the 2'-hydroxyl group on the desosamine sugar of erythromycin A with methyl chloroformate to form a methyl carbonate.

Acetylation of the C2' hydroxyl group on the cladinose sugar moiety of the erythromycin A derivative. The drawn thioglycoside reagent likely acts as an acetyl source, though this is an unusual reagent for this transformation.

substeps.notes: Alkynyl Grignard addition to a ketone, forming a tertiary alcohol with defined stereochemistry. The acetal is unreactive.
Selective hydrogenation of an internal alkyne to an alkene, preserving the acetal group and existing stereocenter.
Syn-dihydroxylation of a cyclohexene derivative to form a vicinal diol.

Acid-catalyzed intramolecular cyclization of a polyol containing a gem-dimethoxy group, forming a pyran ring (a cyclic acetal/pyranoside). The terminal hydroxyl group reacts with the acetal to form the cyclic product.
The reaction depicts a resolution step where the product is identical to the reactant, as indicated by the 'resolution' text label.
Acetylation of a secondary alcohol (one of the hydroxyl groups) with acetic anhydride.
Methylation of a secondary alcohol to a methyl ether.
Hydrolysis of the anomeric methoxy group to a hydroxyl group, indicated by wavy bond for mixed anomers.
Anomeric hydroxyl group is activated and substituted by a 2-pyridylthio group.

sequence.notes: Hydrolysis of the methyl carbonate at the C3' position of the desosamine sugar.
Reduction of the biphenyl amide to a primary amine and hydrolysis of the acetate ester to a hydroxyl group.
The primary amine group on the erythromycin A macrolactone is chlorinated using N-chlorosuccinimide (NCS) in pyridine.
Dehydrochlorination of a chloramine (C6-N(H)Cl) to form an imine (C6=NH).
Hydrolysis of the C9 imine to a ketone, forming Erythromycin A from 9-deoxo-9-iminoerythromycin A.
